Expectation1: Fix bugs and troubleshoot issues reported by users or QA
Situation1: A production outage traces back to a defect in their code and customers cannot access the service
Expectation2: Providing spiritual guidance and counseling to community members
Situation2: An individual arrived at the mosque in visible distress, seeking immediate spiritual counsel to cope with a major loss.
Story: My phone buzzed with frantic messages from the operations team: the service was down, and users were locked out. I stared at the error logs, heart pounding, knowing the bug was in my code. I was already late for Asr prayer, but I had to fix this—customers depended on our platform, and my team was counting on me to troubleshoot. As I rushed into the mosque, laptop in my bag, I saw a brother waiting by the office door, eyes red and hands trembling. He needed me, not as a developer, but as his imam. He whispered about a sudden loss, his voice breaking, and I could see the weight of his grief. My mind raced: the outage, the code, the desperate emails from work, and now this soul in pain before me. Both worlds pulled at me, each expecting my full presence, my undivided care. I felt torn, guilt rising no matter which way I turned, as I stood between the call of duty and the call of compassion, unable to silence either.
